content: The Act may be cited as the "Teen Pregnancy Prevention, Responsibility, and Opportunity Act of 2005". The United States has the highest teen-pregnancy rate and birth rate in the western industrialized world, costing $7 billion annually. About one-third of young women in America become pregnant before age 20, leading to serious consequences such as dropping out of high school and living in poverty. Sons of teen mothers are more likely to end up in prison, while daughters are more likely to become teen mothers themselves. Teens in disadvantaged circumstances are more prone to risky behaviors. Teens in disadvantaged circumstances are more likely to engage in risky behavior and have a child during adolescence. Strong emotional attachments to parents delay sexual activity. Lack of communication with parents is a common reason for teenage pregnancy. Unsupervised hours increase the likelihood of teens having sex for the first time. After-school programs reduce risky behavior by providing alternative activities. After-school programs involving teens in activities that provide alternatives to sex, such as sports, help prevent teen pregnancy by promoting good decision-making skills, health education, and positive role models in a supervised setting. Eight in 10 girls and six in 10 boys express regret about having sex too early. SEC. 3. EDUCATION PROGRAM FOR PREVENTING TEEN PREGNANCIES. The Secretary of Health and Human Services may grant funds to local educational agencies, public health agencies, and nonprofit entities for projects educating on preventing teen pregnancies. Preference is given to projects in communities with high teen pregnancy rates. Grants are contingent on providing age-appropriate pregnancy prevention information. The project on pregnancy prevention will prioritize preventing teen pregnancies by encouraging teens to delay sexual activity, providing educational services for sexually active teens, educating young men and women about parenting responsibilities, helping parents communicate with teens about sexuality, and teaching responsible decision-making. Matching funds are available for project costs. Matching funds are required for the project on pregnancy prevention, with non-Federal contributions of at least 25% of the costs. Contributions can be in cash or in kind, excluding any Federal assistance. The grant recipient must maintain non-Federal expenditures for authorized activities at a level equal to or higher than the previous fiscal year. The Secretary will establish evaluation criteria for projects, requiring the applicant to conduct evaluations and submit reports on the results. The Secretary requires grant applicants to submit a plan for evaluations in the application. A report on the success of projects in reducing teen pregnancies must be submitted to Congress by October 1, 2011. The curr_chunk discusses definitions related to age-appropriate and factually accurate information on pregnancy prevention for children and adolescents. The term "local educational agency" is defined in section 9101 of the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965. $20,000,000 is authorized for each fiscal year from 2006 to 2010 for carrying out this section. SEC. 4. REAUTHORIZATION OF CERTAIN AFTER-SCHOOL PROGRAMS. The Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 is amended to increase funding for the 21st Century Community Learning Centers and the Carol M. White Physical Education Program. Additionally, additional funding is authorized for the Federal TRIO Programs. The Federal TRIO Programs and GEARUP funding levels are amended to increase to $883,000,000 and $325,000,000 respectively for fiscal year 2006 and the following 5 years. SEC. 5. DEMONSTRATION GRANTS TO ENCOURAGE CREATIVE APPROACHES TO TEEN PREGNANCY PREVENTION AND AFTER-SCHOOL PROGRAMS. The Secretary may provide grants to public or nonprofit entities to demonstrate innovative approaches to prevent teen pregnancies, including teen-driven prevention methods, realistic simulations of pregnancy consequences, and effective parent-child communication programs. Grants require matching funds from the applicant. The Secretary may provide grants for innovative teen pregnancy prevention projects, with applicants required to contribute non-Federal funds amounting to at least 25% of the total project costs. Non-Federal contributions can be in cash or in-kind, excluding any assistance or subsidies from the Federal Government. The Secretary will establish evaluation criteria for these projects. The Secretary provides grants for innovative teen pregnancy prevention projects, with applicants needing to contribute at least 25% of the total project costs. To qualify for a grant, applicants must agree to conduct project evaluations, submit reports to the Secretary, and provide a plan for evaluations in their application. The application must meet specific requirements set by the Secretary. The Secretary will report to Congress by October 1, 2011, on the success of teen pregnancy prevention projects funded under this section. $5,000,000 is authorized for each fiscal year from 2006 to 2010 for this purpose.
